subsection.title: Equations and Solutions
subsection.p: In this section we review some techniques and terminology related to equations, inequalities, and their graphs.

definition.title: Solution
definition.p: A solutionsolution of an equation is a value of the variable that makes the equation true.

subsection.p: For example, x = \alert{−2} is a solution of the equation 4x^3 + 5x^2 -8x = 4 because 4(\alert{−2})^3 + 5(\alert{−2})^2 - 8(\alert{−2}) = -2 + 20 + 16 = 4.

statement.p: Which of the following values are solutions of the equation -2x^3+x^2+16x=15\text{?}

subsection.p: A linear equation, such as the models we studied in the last section, has at most one solution. We find the solution by transforming the equation into a simpler equivalent equation whose solution is obvious.

statement.p: Find the solution of the equation 16 - 2(3x - 1) = 4x + 2(x - 3).

subsection.title: Linear Inequalities
subsection.p: Although a linear equation can have at most one solution, a linear inequality can have many solutions. For example, complete the table of values for the expression 5 − 2x:
Now use your table to list at least three solutions of the inequality 5 - 2x \lt 2.

statement.p: Use algebra to solve the inequality ~~5 -2x \lt 2.

solution.p: We begin by isolating the term containing the variable, just as we do when solving a linear equation. We subtract 5 from both sides to obtain -2x \lt -3 Then we divide both sides by −2 to find x\gt \frac{-3}{-2}\amp =\frac{3}{2}\amp\amp\blert{\text{Reverse the direction of the inequality.}} Any value of x greater than \frac{3}{2} is a solution of the inequality. We write the solutions as x \gt \frac{3}{2}. Because we cannot list all of these solutions, we often illustrate them as a graph on a number line, as shown below.

subsection.p: In the Example above, we used the following rule for solving linear inequalities.

assemblage.title: Solving a Linear Inequality
assemblage.p: If we multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a negative number, we must reverse the direction of the inequality.

subsection.p: Other than the rule stated in the box above, the rules for solving a linear inequality are the same as the rules for solving a linear equation.

subsection.title: Equations in Two Variables
subsection.p: An equation in two variables, such as -3x + 4y = 24 has many solutions. Each solution consists of an ordered pair of values, one for x and one for y, that together satisfy the equation (make the equation true.)

webwork.pg-code: $which = RadioButtons( ["A value of \(x \) that makes the equation true.", "An ordered pair of values \((x,y) \) that satisfy the equation.", "Solving the equation for \(y\) in terms of \(x \).", "The graph of the equation."], 1, );

statement.p: What is the solution of an equation in two variables?

solution.p: An ordered pair of values (x,y) that satisfy the equation.

li.p: Is (2,7.5) a solution of the equation ~-3x+4y=24?
Is (4,3) a solution of the equation ~-3x+4y=24?
The ordered pair (2,7.5) is a solution of the equation above, because it satifies the equation. -3(\alert{2})+4(\alert{7.5})=-6+30=24
The ordered pair (4,3) is not a solution, because it does not satify the equation. -3(\alert{4})+4(\alert{3})=-12+12=0\ne 24

subsection.title: What is the Graph of an Equation?

definition.title: Graph
definition.p: The graphgraph of an equation in two variables is just a picture of all its solutions.

subsection.p: You might think it would be difficult to find all the solutions of an equation, but for a linear equation Ax + By = C, we can at least illustrate the solutions: all the solutions lie on a straight line. (Later on we can prove that this is true.)

li.p: All the solutions of a linear equation in two variables lie on a straight line.
The equation -3x + 4y = 24 is a linear equation.
The graph of an equation in two variables is a picture of its solutions.
If a point lies on the graph of an equation, it is a solution of the equation.

sidebyside.p:
The figure shows a graph of the equation ~Ax + By = C. Which of the following equations are true?
24B=C
Ap+Bq=C
Ag+Bh=C

li.p: The point (0, 24) lies on the graph, so x = 0, y = 24 is a solution of the equation. Thus, A \cdot 0 + B \cdot 24 = C, or 24B = C is a true statement.
The point (p, q) does not lie on the graph, so x = p, y = q does not satisfy the equation, and A p+ B q = C is a not true.
The point (g,h ) does lie on the graph, so x = g, y = h does satisfy the equation, and A g+ B h = C is a true statement.

subsection.title: Graphical Solution of Equations
subsection.p: We can use graphs to find solutions to equations in one variable.

statement.p: Use the graph of ~y = 285 - 15x~ to solve the equation 150 = 285 - 15x

stack.p: Compare the two equations in the problem. In the equation we want to solve, y has been replaced by \alert{150}. We begin by locating the point P on the graph for which y = 150.
Next we find the x-coordinate of point P by drawing an imaginary line from P straight down to the x-axis. The x-coordinate of P is x = 9.
Thus, P is the point (9,150), and x = 9 when y = 150. The solution we seek is x = 9.

solution.p: You can verify the solution algebraically by substituting x = \alert{9} into the equation:

note.p:
The relationship between an equation and its graph is an important one. For the previous example, make sure you understand that the following three statement sare equivalent.
The point (9, 150) lies on the graph of y = 285 - 15x.
The ordered pair (9, 150) is a solution of the equation y = 285 - 15x.
x=9 is a solution of the equation 150 = 285 - 15x.

subsection.title: Graphical Solution of Inequalities
subsection.p: We can also use graphs to solve inequalities. Consider the inequality 285-15x \ge 150 To solve this inequality means finding all values of x that make the expression 285 -15x greater than or equal to 150. We could begin by trying some values of x. Here is a table obtained by evaluating 285 − 15x.
From the table, we see that values of x less than or equal to 8 are solutions of the inequality, but we have not checked all possible x-values. We can get a more complete picture from a graph.

statement.p: Use the graph of the equation ~y = 285 - 15x~ to solve the inequality 285 - 15x \gt 150

stack.p: We look for points on the graph with y-coordinates greater than or equal to 150. These points are shown in color. Which x-values produced these points?

We can read the x-coordinates by dropping straight down to the x-axis, as shown by the arows. For example, the x-value corresponding to y=150 is x=9. For larger values of 285-15x, we must choose x-values less than 9. Thus, all values of x less than or equal to 9 are solutions, as shown on the x-axis.

solution.p: We write the solutions as x \le 9.

subsection.title: Using a Graphing Utility
subsection.p: We can use a graphing utility to graph equations if they are written in the form ~y = (\text{expression in }x)~. First, let's review how to solve an equation for y in terms of x.

statement.p: Solve the equation ~6x-5y=90~ for y in terms of x.
Solve for y in terms of x: \quad 10y-15x=6

subsection.p: Now we are ready to graph an equation with technology. On most calculators, we follow three steps.

li.p: Press Y= and enter the equation you wish to graph.
Press WINDOW and select a graphing window.
Press GRAPH.

subsection.p: Choosing a graphing window corresponds to drawing the x- and y-axes and marking a scale on each axis when we graph by hand. The standard graphing window displays values from -10 to 10 on both axes. We can press the ZOOM key and then the number 6 to select this window.

statement.p: Use a graphing utility to graph the equation 3x + 2y = 16.

sidebyside.p: Now press Y= and enter -1.5x+8 after Y_1=. (Use the negation key, (-), to enter -1.5x; do not use the subtraction key.) We choose the standard graphing window by pressing ZOOM 6. The graph is shown at right.

subsection.p: When you want to erase the graph, press Y= and then press CLEAR. This deletes the expression following Y_1.

subsection.title: Finding Coordinates with a Graphing Calculator
subsection.p: We can use the TRACE feature to find the coordinates of points on a graph.

statement.p: Use a graph to find a solution to the equation y = -2.6x - 5.4 with y-coordinate -10.6.
